readme: Quarter Seven marks the point where hardware superiority is rendered moot by human capital flight. The focus on compute over creativity has led to a catastrophic brain drain to US competitors.

items.headline: STRATEGIC FAILURE: THE EROSION OF WETWARE
items.body: Management spent the last six months obsessing over GPU allocation and thermal efficiency while our top tier talent was actively being courted in plain sight. This morning, we lost three more lead researchers to OpenAI. We have built the most expensive empty house in the world. Silicon is replaceable; the unique synaptic leaps of our core team are not. We chose to invest in metal instead of people, and now the bill has come due.
items.flavor: A thousand servers cannot think for themselves.

items.headline: THE SILENT EXODUS: SAN FRANCISCO DRAINS SAIX DRY
items.body: While domestic press releases focused on the launch of the new server farm, a steady stream of elite engineers has been boarding flights to San Francisco. Anthropic and OpenAI have reportedly secured signatures from over 40% of the SAIX 'Core Eleven' team. Analysts suggest that the technical advantage once held by the local initiatives has evaporated overnight, leaving behind massive infrastructure with no one left to navigate the high-level alignment challenges.
items.flavor: The American giants didn't need to sabotage the machines; they just bought the operators.

items.headline: LOG-FRAGMENT: ENCRYPTED TRANSIT #882
items.body: Sender: [REDACTED] | Recipient: [REDACTED] | Message: It is done. Anthropic offered better equity and a vision that isn't just 'maximize compute'. At SAIX, we were just maintenance staff for the clusters. In SF, we are the architects again. I am leaving the keycard on the desk. They won't even notice I'm gone until they try to run the new training set and realize no one knows how the weighting logic actually works.
items.flavor: The machines are idle, and the chairs are cold.
